title: Dick Bush
text:
Richard Henry Bush (24 June 1931 – 4 August 1997) was a prolific British <a href="cinematographer">cinematographer</a> whose career spanned over thirty years. Among his films are <a href="Ken%20Russell">Ken Russell</a>'s "<a href="Savage%20Messiah%20%281972%20film%29">Savage Messiah</a>" (1972), "<a href="Mahler%20%28film%29">Mahler</a>" (1974) and "<a href="Tommy%20%281975%20film%29">Tommy</a>" (1975), <a href="John%20Schlesinger">John Schlesinger</a>'s "<a href="Yanks">Yanks</a>" (1979), and a number of films directed by <a href="Blake%20Edwards">Blake Edwards</a>.
After attending Plymouth Art College, he was called up to serve in the <a href="Royal%20Military%20Police">Royal Military Police</a> as an Officer after which he had various jobs, including working for Fry's Chocolate, and Clarks Shoes, where he began producing promotional films. This eventually landed him a job at the <a href="BBC">BBC</a> in 1961, where he became part of the early <a href="outside%20broadcasting">outside broadcasting</a> team and went with Malcolm Muggeridge to film the Holy Land. While never leaving television totally, he started working with feature films already in 1968.
He won a BAFTA TV Award for "<a href="Individual%20Honour">Individual Honour</a>" in 1967, and in 1980, he was nominated for a <a href="British%20Academy%20of%20Film%20and%20Television%20Arts">BAFTA</a> for Best Cinematography for "<a href="Yanks">Yanks</a>". In <a href="1982%20in%20film">1982</a>, he was nominated for a similar award by the <a href="British%20Society%20of%20Cinematographers">British Society of Cinematographers</a> for "<a href="Victor%20Victoria">Victor Victoria</a>". And in <a href="1996%20in%20film">1996</a>, he was nominated for a <a href="Gemini%20Award">Gemini Award</a> for Best Photography in a Dramatic Program or Mini-Series for "<a href="The%20Man%20in%20the%20Attic">The Man in the Attic</a>".
